title: How to Make Arabian Bread

steps.headline: Add the ingredients to a mixing bowl.
steps.description: Mix together until it forms a dough.

steps.headline: Move the dough to a floured surface.
Leave it to rise for half an hour.
steps.description: Place a tea towel over it to help keep it warm and to keep it safe from insects, etc.

steps.headline: Cut the dough into an even amount of small pieces.
steps.description: Cut them into the size of an egg.

steps.headline: Roll out the dough eggs as thinly as you can.
Bake the bread on a non-stick pan.
Place the yeast into a small bowl.
steps.description: Add slightly warmed water and the sugar. Put aside to develop.

steps.headline: Add the flour, milk powder and salt to a large mixing bowl.
steps.description: Make a well in the center of the dry ingredients.

steps.headline: Pour the oil and yeast liquid into the dry ingredients, into the well.
Stir to combine.
steps.description: If needed, add more flour to improve the consistency. Stir until a dough forms.

steps.headline: Remove from the bowl and place on a floured surface.
Divide the dough into 18 even sized balls.
steps.description: Let sit on the floured surface. Cover with a clean tea towel and leave to sit for 15 to 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Gently warm up a heavy-based skillet.
steps.description: Cast iron skillets are ideal for this purpose.

steps.headline: Roll out a ball of dough to flatter it.
steps.description: Add to the skillet and heat until you see it forming large bubbles or holes. Turn it over and cook the other side for another few minutes. Squash down with the flat side of a spatula.

steps.headline: Remove the first pita bread and place on a plate.
steps.description: Wrap a tea towel around it to keep it warm. Alternatively, place cooked pita inside a resealable bag to keep it warm.

steps.headline: Repeat with the remaining 17 balls of dough.
Serve warm.
steps.description: Serve with hummus, tabouli, falafel and other foods, as needed. Store in the fridge for up to 2 days or freeze, wrapped, for up to 3 months.

text: Arabian bread Add the ingredients to a mixing bowl. Mix together until it forms a dough. Move the dough to a floured surface. Knead the dough well. Leave it to rise for half an hour. Place a tea towel over it to help keep it warm and to keep it safe from insects, etc. Cut the dough into an even amount of small pieces. Cut them into the size of an egg. Roll out the dough eggs as thinly as you can.  Bake the bread on a non-stick pan. Bake on both sides. Serve warm.  Pita bread Place the yeast into a small bowl. Add slightly warmed water and the sugar. Put aside to develop. Add the flour, milk powder and salt to a large mixing bowl. Make a well in the center of the dry ingredients. Pour the oil and yeast liquid into the dry ingredients, into the well.  Stir to combine. If needed, add more flour to improve the consistency. Stir until a dough forms. Remove from the bowl and place on a floured surface. Knead lightly. Divide the dough into 18 even sized balls. Let sit on the floured surface. Cover with a clean tea towel and leave to sit for 15 to 30 minutes. Gently warm up a heavy-based skillet. Cast iron skillets are ideal for this purpose. Roll out a ball of dough to flatter it. Add to the skillet and heat until you see it forming large bubbles or holes. Turn it over and cook the other side for another few minutes. Squash down with the flat side of a spatula. Remove the first pita bread and place on a plate. Wrap a tea towel around it to keep it warm. Alternatively, place cooked pita inside a resealable bag to keep it warm. Repeat with the remaining 17 balls of dough.  Serve warm. Serve with hummus, tabouli, falafel and other foods, as needed. Store in the fridge for up to 2 days or freeze, wrapped, for up to 3 months.
